did.abstract: Ann Arbor, Michigan, civic activist involved with housing and civil rights issues and organizations. Subject files relating to her work with the Ann Arbor Citizens Committee for Fair Housing Legislation and its successor organization, the Ann Arbor Committee for Housing Legislation; also files relating to the Ann Arbor Housing Commission, the Ann Arbor Human Relations Commission, and the Off-Campus Housing Bureau of the University of Michigan Office of Student Community Relations.

bioghist.p: Norma F. Kraker was a former Ann Arbor resident who was active in local organizations involved with the enactment and enforcement of anti-discrimination laws in the City of Ann Arbor and at the University of Michigan campus. She worked in the Off-Campus Housing Office of the University of Michigan from 1963 to 1974, where she worked to eliminate racial discrimination in private student housing in Ann Arbor. From 1961 to 1962, she was the executive secretary of the Ann Arbor Committee for Fair Housing Legislation. She served on the Ann Arbor Human Relations Commission from January 1963 to June 1965. She was reappointed in 1965 but resigned in 1967. In 1968, she joined the Ann Arbor Housing Commission, serving until 1972. From 1970-1971, she helped plan the Model Cities program for the City of Ann Arbor. Kraker was also active in efforts designed to create more affordable public housing in Ann Arbor, most notably the Miller Manor. She also had a strong interest in housing for the elderly and in general civil rights issues.

scopecontent.p: The Norma F. Kraker Collection consists of five series relating to her many public responsibilities. The series in the collection include: Ann Arbor Committee for Fair Housing Legislation; Ann Arbor Housing Commission; Ann Arbor Human Relations Commission; Model Cities Program; and the University of Michigan, Office of Off-Campus Housing.

did.unittitle: Ann Arbor Citizens Committee for Fair Housing Legislation

note.p: (later Ann Arbor Committee for Housing Legislation)

scopecontent.p: The Ann Arbor Committee for Fair Housing Legislation series is made up of minutes and correspondence from 1961 to 1962. The minutes are arranged chronologically while correspondence is arranged both incoming and outgoing.

The Ann Arbor Housing Commission series covers the period 1968 to 1972. It consists of minutes, correspondence, contracts, financial statements, Miller Manor Publication, and papers concerning public housing sites in Ann Arbor. Minutes are arranged chronologically; correspondence is also chronological and both incoming and outgoing. Contracts pertain to the Commission's contracts with private companies and with the federal government. Financial statements are available for the Commission for the years 1968 to 1970, and 1972. Miller Manor Publications are "in-house" newsletters. Public Housing Sites papers contain correspondence, memos, and housing site charts.

The Ann Arbor Human Relations Commission series documents the years 1962 to 1967. It contains minutes, correspondence, and a publication of the Commission. Minutes are arranged chronologically. Correspondence is also chronologically arranged and is both incoming and outgoing. The publication included here: "The Population Distribution of Racial Minorities in Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1950-1960," is not a publication Mrs. Kraker worked on, but is included here as an example of one of the issues with which she was concerned.

scopecontent.p: The University of Michigan, Office of Off-Campus Housing series consists of correspondence from 1963 to 1971 and from 1973 to 1974. It is arranged chronologically by year and is both incoming and outgoing. Here may be found the majority of personal outgoing correspondence written by Mrs. Kraker.
